_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Dead River Company's (Dead River's) Hampden propane bulk storage facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LP-Gas storage.  It is Dead River's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is Dead River's policy to notify the Hampden Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. The Manager of Propane Rail Terminals acts as the company First Responder for propane emergencies.  He has received formal training at the Massachusetts Fire Academy and attends annual refresher training there as well.  Dead River maintains a First Response Vehicle at the Hampden location that is for use at any location during emergencies.  Dead River has an outreach program to offer summer propane fire training burns and instructional training to local fire departments for the purpose of educating fire departments about the hazards of propane. 

The Hampden facility is a bulk terminal storing propane (LPG) for resale to retail propane outlets. The facility consists of eight 30,000-gallon tanks with a total storage capacity of 211,000 gallons at maximum fill level (88%). 

The worst-case release scenario is the rupture of a 30,000-gallon tank when filled to the greatest extent allowed (88%) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite 0.4 miles, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint. The alternative release scenario is a break in a 3" diameter pipe, leading to a 10-minute release and explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite 0.08 miles, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and other applicable state and local codes and regulations. The propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and state laws and rules (Maine Fuel Board).   Protective measures include but are not limited to security fencing, redundan

t emergency valves on all inlet and outlet piping, breakaway fittings at all cargo truck loading areas, emergency relief valves, and impact protection measures for all loading and unloading areas.   Currently there are no planned changes necessary to improve facility safety.  

Dead River has never had an accident involving propane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place.  In the event of an emergency involving the Hampden facility's propane system, it is Dead River's policy to notify the Hampden Fire Department and request that they help respond to the emergency.  Dead River also has a trained fire brigade. We have coordinated our response plans with the fire department; members of the fire department have inspected our propane system and conducted a joint exercise with us. 

The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities is organized into 9 Sections.   Since this facility only has flammable and no toxic chemicals covered under 40 CFR 68, and because it is a Program 3 Propane Storage facility with no history of accidents, several of the sections do not apply.
